title: Obscurity Here We Come
review:
OMG. Well it is strange time in America politically socially geopolitically and psychologically. Even the weather is odd. So we expect movies to reflect that and nothing reflects that more than this god-awful gratuitous remake that somehow managed to lose all the good human bits of the TV movie and leave behind only the bitter husk.

Aside from taking bullying to a new low, you have to believe that not even Stephen King (no longer a literary icon in the Youtube age) would prefer that this film have never been made at all rather than have it as part of his legacy.

Recommendation: watch the original. Read The Stand. Watch The Stand. Go repaint the garage. Just avoid this.

title: Average adaption - too many horror set-pieces and ear-bleedingly loud
review:
IT could have been a horror classic. Instead we have an okay film which doesn't quite grip as it should, and two hours after seeing it is already starting to fade from my memory.

Part of the problem is that Pennywise is a bit overused. Bill Skarsgard does a good job, but he pops up roughly every five minutes or so, and his effectiveness is diminished as the film goes on - until the climax, when the creepiness factor goes into overdrive.

The child actors are all okay, but some of "The Losers Club" are underdeveloped. Mike Hanlon's interest in the history of Derry is transferred to Ben Hanscom, which left very little to go on. Mike is thinly sketched and so is Richie. It fumbles Eddie's story very badly.

It was probably just the cinema I saw it in, but the volume was way too loud - it was ear-splitting. And as the film, as so many modern horror films do, over relies on jump cuts, it felt like a jack hammer each time it happened. Jumpcuts don't improve a horror film, they are a cheap go to for lazy film makers, and there were too many of them in this movie. Too many horror set pieces in general, and more character stuff needed for me.

There are some good moments,though. Stan's creepy painting - a sequence not in the novel - really works, though again it means reducing characterisation, as we get to know Stan through his bird watching in Stephen King's novel. He's also a boy scout, another aspect totally gone. Ben's library encounter with Pennywise is also effectively spooky....a trail of little Easter eggs leading straight to Pennywise. Beverly Marsh was really well done, until she apparently killed her dad - WTF? - and Henry Bowers is much more effective than he was in the t.v. adaption.

I'm also pleased that some of the background to Derry made it into the film, though did it really need to be updated to the 80s? Part of the book's charm is that it is set in the late 50s. I can't get nostalgic over the era of Ronald Reagan and awful music. I missed a lot of the "growing up" stuff from the book. This was a movie that badly needed more character development.

All told, though, I enjoyed it to a degree, and I will be back for part two. Maybe more enjoyable if you haven't read the book or seen the much loved t.v. mini-series.

title: All the quality of a made for Netflix movie
review:
Personally, I thought all the CGI buried Skarsgard's performance, I have no idea if he is interesting in this role or not. The film is rife with overplayed, standard horror imagery right out of the modern playbook (if I see the stutter cut monster run one more time...) and it's all very, very tired.

There is very little imagination in scares, they have no weight or meaning. The whole thing feels like a YA horror story made for Netflix.

Sophia Lillis and Jeremy Ray Taylor are breakout stars though, they're fun to watch, but in a standout year for horror, IT wasn't it.

Hopefully, you enjoy it more than I did. I certainly seem to be in the minority here.

title: Completely misses the boat on what a genuine horror movie should be
review:
Not sure what to say about this particular box-office hit that's smashing records in the horror genre. But after having watched a late night showing and going in with a lot of hope and positive thoughts, it seems this movie relied on the clichéd jump-scare style of horror film-making and an over use of CGI which I feared would happen. It's unfortunate that it completely lost an incredible opportunity to be a truly nerve-wracking and genuinely scary flick. From the looks of it, it's been targeted more so towards very young people in the 12-16 range despite the rating being R.

On the positives, what we have is amazing cinematography, some fairly skilled young actors, and an antagonist who happens to be a monster dressed as a clown that kills children. Basically all the ingredients to serve up something brilliant on screen. It misses the mark there completely which is a real shame.

To compare like to like, the 1990 television-movie was a lot more frightening. Mainly because Tim Curry was brilliant in the role and the child-actors seemed a bit older and had more character development and more chemistry among each other as a group than these new young actors.

The first 7-8 minutes is top notch from the introduction of Bill and Georgie up to the intro of the monster. It's done brilliantly but then flat lines and falls from there.

One thing this movie doesn't rely on is silence at any time outside of the opening segment. There's an underlying score playing in almost every single scene. It might be more apparent when watching the movie in Ultra AVX Atmos surround sound but it goes against the powerful method of film making where sometimes less is more and damages the impact that silence can have during very intense scenes. Sort of like the use of almost no music during the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre. You can just feel the intensity and seriousness of the situation in many parts of that film and unfortunately that's spoiled here with far too much background score playing for no reason whatsoever. It's Hollywood's way to try to make things more epic and Hollywoodesque I suppose. Just way overdone which kills the mood and atmosphere. But that's just my personal gripe. Others may not care as much.

Obviously I can't throw in spoilers but this is a movie you'd be better off watching on TV whenever it releases and saving your money and time. Whatever you're expecting from this, forget it. It's a huge disappointment unless you're 12-16 years of age and have seen very few to no horror films in the past.

Too much CGI, too much unnecessary music overplaying to the point of ruining the atmosphere, too much reliance on jump scares that are overused in horror films nowadays, a clown that isn't all that scary, and a lack of character development overall. Save your money for something better.

title: Horrible Movie
review: Please! Don't waste your time or money. The teens acting is alright but the movies is horrible. There were no scary parts to make you jump and a lot of the movie is actually comical being so bad. The quality of the film and some effects are good, but you'll most likely be disappointed. Hope this is helpful.

title: A computer generated abomination ofa film
review:
I hated this film after the opening scene. The actor who portrays It is great but Hollywood needs everything done on powerpoint so it ages like crap. Why use a great actor when we can create a clown with CG and take away any possibility of It being scary. This decision alone destroyed the film.

I also think a horror film that doesn't manage to be scary is a complete failure. It's like a comedic movie that isn't funny.

title: Scarier before I saw 'It'
review: Felt as though the scares were as artificial as most the terror. Too-polished, CGI-heavy effects that didn't land like I thought they would; didn't feel very palpable, and it was jarring from the tension. Having grown up traumatized by the original movie, my anticipation of the remake gave me more anxiety that the actual movie. Also seemed as though it took too many liberties with its own mythos for me to take it too seriously. I'll watch the 2nd chapter, but now with a dash of salted skepticism.

title: Overrated and uninspired chlichefest
review:
This movie is painfully boring and way too long, the structure is completely meaningless nonesense (2 climaxes seperated by more boring filler). The first half stands out featuring about 20 different cliches and cringeworthy kids dialogue. Pennywise is not scary at all and his wiggling and cgi teeth make me laugh (which is bad for a horror film)

My advice would be watching the opening scene on youtube and be done with it.

3/10 uninsprired and a wate of time

title: Made for an audience that should not be watching
review: This film was clearly made for an audiance of younger viewers - and those viewers should clearly not be watching this film. Its a collection of loose scenes - at its best with some not too scary jump-scares. Not for me!

title: when dealing with an evil entity, sometimes you gotta be creepy
review:
I've never read Stephen King's novel about a supremely evil force that terrorizes a Maine town, but this adaptation is worth seeing. Bill Skarsgård plays Pennywise as a truly malevolent being who knows just how to get into people's confidence. Basically, 2017's "It" is a creepy movie that hits the right notes. The children do a fine job with their roles. Like some of Stephen King's other works - "The Body" (adapted as "Stand by Me") and "Hearts in Atlantis" - it does a good job showing how the adults are lousy role models, so the children join up to achieve something. But make no mistake, Skarsgård is the real star. Don't be surprised if you want to sleep with the light on after seeing his performance.

I also recommend the 1990 miniseries, and I hope to read the novel. Good one.

title: Disappointed, wasted time.
review:
Desperate effort to make bunch of kids look cool without any particular story, dialogue or acting. Entire movie with missing kids where the adults aren't anywhere, & kids act like super adults.
One of the most non sense movies. The clown is the worst. It's not scary or funny but irrational many times which irritates a lot.

title: It was so boring that I fell asleep in theater... Then loud noise waked me up.
review:
People inters a clown show, young children, women, men and all short of people. The show was going well. But an accident sets fire on the entire hall room. It burns everything, all the people, all the cute laughing faces of the children. But the dancing clown of the show who had heavy paint all over his face and baggy cloths on him, manages to escape the fire. Out of the hall he jumps into a sewer to put the fire of his body. Later, instead of showing up above, he stays down the sewer. Cos he realizes it was he who was responsible for the fire. He could not show his face to anybody cos what he had done. Neither could he forgive himself.

The clown never forgot the melting face of the children. Which he never wanted. He wanted to all the children smile and laugh. That was his fantasy, that's what he still wants. But he could not come above ! Because the above world reminds him of that horrible event.

So being a vigilante he starts kidnaping kids one by one using his charisma. He takes them down the sewer and looks them up in a cage. He tells them jokes, serves them nice food and cloths, dances in front of them. Just for one reason ! he wants to see them smiling and laughing. He succeds for first few times but then the kids starts getting desperate to go home. The clown insists. He would do anything, bring them anything but they can't leave him. He want's them to SMILE. The kids soon realizes they are in deep trouble.

The clown plans to bring some more kids into his show. But this time he makes a little mistake. He tries to lure a kid whose brother was already captivated by him. The kid was too smart and realized what happened to his brother. He runs back to home.

He tries to explain this to his and all the children's parents but no one believes him. So he decides to rescue his brother on his own.

Down the sewer, the three captivated kids also tries to trick the clown in different way to escape form. But the clown is super smart (and scary). He is not easy to be fooled.

So, this time the kids takes a different approach. They asks the clown to bring them strange things for them, like cartoon dvds, toys, video games, carrots etc. Their plan was to keep the clown busy so they can find way escape. But every time the clown successfully brings it to them within an hour.

butt, butt, butt, wait there, that's not the story...

Yeah, that's not the story, I just made it up. You wanna know the story? cos there is no story in this movie. Just bunch of scenes tied up together. And if you watch a lots of movie, than you have seen them already.

Door slamming behind... zombie like creature walking toward the victim slowly... Kids in creepy house... Screaming, screaming, screaming and some more screaming... One character gets extracted from the team... Blood coming out of wash basin... The antagonist floating in the air ??? Creepy noise from the next room...

title: It Sucked. *May contain spoilers*
review:
This has got to be the most over-hyped movie ever made. I can't believe the (supposedly professional) reviews elsewhere online calling this move a smash success. They must be inflating the ratings, and suppressing bad press for this costly disaster.

There was no chemistry between the kids... At. All. Beverly looked like Little Orphan Annie... She was not very good at faking a nervous smoking habit, which they tried to imply she had, and just about everything those kids did/said, was incredibly stupid. The whole thing was like a bad joke. The dialog is just insulting, and the "scary" parts were just gore or jump scares. I was never less emotionally invested in a set of characters. I found myself wishing Pennywise would just gobble them all up and be done with it.

It absolutely dragged too. About the only thing they "improved" was the role of Henry as the murderous bully. He was truly horrific.

Everything that made the original so good was missing with nothing of value added.

If you've always wanted a version of IT, without any heart, humor, subtly, intrigue or fear...This your movie!

Fake looking CGI's galore, plenty of predictability, as well as "Said No One Ever" dialog, and "I could care less about these kids" character development. Throw in ridiculousness, and throw out any hope of not being bored to death long before IT's over...And there you have it! A marvelous film for the intellectually challenged with nothing better to do.

title: So disappointing
review: First time I saw the trailer I was really hoping for something creepy, psychological scare. I did get none of that. Jumpscares and CGI. Loved the book, liked the original IT mini series and then This comes along. The acting by the kids is good but too much joking around for my liking. Not really ever you feel like they are in serious trouble. And the people around these kids feel so futile. You don't really ever care about anyone or what happens to them in this movie. The first 15 minutes was really nice. But after that it's all downhill. One thing I don't get how people praise the performance by Bill Skarsgård as Pennywise. What did he actually do? Eyes moving in different directions, that's it? It was so obvious that his lines was ADR or post-sync (what ever you call it). Surely by himself, I don't deny that. But otherwise he just stood there and made some faces and the rest was CGI. Wow, surely an Oscar performance there. Really overrated. Hardly any remake comes close to the original and this is far from that. Avoid this movie, you won't miss anything.

title: IT was brilliant but not a horror its more a comedy
review: this movie was brilliant really enjoyed it, although I thought it would be a horror movie it was more of a comedy, we laughed almost all the way through. Its well worth a watch the acting is superb and I found it to be much better than the first movie, just a shame it weren't scary as we thought it would be, overall id give a 9 out of 10 but think the rating should be a PG :)

title: Awful
review: This movie ruined the soul of the book for me. I didn't understand if this was a comedy or a horror. Stephen King does not write comedy's like that. The kids are so annoying in this movie, their acting is so wrong for IT. They are against a creature like IT and they are so childish. They look so "heroic". The kids are the stars, Pennywise is just something to beat. That looks really lame to me. It is also giving more attention to the relationship between Bev and Bill then the character of Pennywise or anything else. ﻿

title: A Potty Mouth Adaptation that misses the point
review:
This movie is filled with ridiculous amounts of profanity after another by little kids telling jokes every few minutes because people think kids yelling the F word, C word, S word is funny. Not, this movie is horrible and completely misses the point of what It is supposed to be. It is supposed be terrifying, dangerous, grueling, grim, and depressing. Not this joke fest they've made. Completely overdone and only has 10% of gore of what the book has to offer. This film was supposed to offer NC-17 level violence and even controversial scenes such as a child having sex with another child. There's none of that in here. There's only an arm rip scene, which was done in the most non-disgusting way. Probably because Hollywood has a cynical view of cinema and they can't go all out because they're too wussy to take their ambitions to greater heights. The production is mediocre. Lots of fake looking sets, cheap digital effects that may put the audience off. The child performances are horrible as always. Just straight up cringe. Bill Skarsgaard is okay, but at times he is way too obvious. Once again, a horror film reduced to dumb characters making very dumb decisions. The cinematography was standard, shot composition was below average, lighting wasn't too good, color grading is the blue and orange teal and every Hollywood movie. Do yourself a favor and save yourself from It. It will just irritate your mind the more you watch It.

2/10.

title: Awfully bad
review:
First of all, is there anyone out there who is not sick to death of remakes? Seriously. Can you take it? And what excuses do they have for making these remakes? That they can tell the story in a better or more creative way? Has any remake ever accomplished that? Of course not.

This film has no respect for the original, and it doesn't understand (or try to understand) what the film is about. You see, the original film was about friendship, about confronting fear, about the power of faith, and about a really creepy presence menacing the kids. This film just has a silly monster doing silly things, but there is no real purpose to it. The monster doesn't seem to know what it wants, and the kids look like they are just puppets for the monster to abuse. They never become the likable characters from the original, that become true friends and struggle to overcome their weaknesses and fears. Thus, in the remake, all we have is a bunch of kids being scared at random by a CGI monster. The film seems to wish to compensate for lack of substance by turning the violence up. In the original, the fat kid is threatened with a knife, but not actually cut. Here he does get cut, and the rock throwing episode is a real war, with people getting seriously hurt. Likewise, the scenes with 'it' are protracted, yet pointless. You see, the monster in the original film had a clear sense of purpose, and the confrontations with it were not so much about action, but the meaning behind it. This film has no meaning, but it has lots of silly action that really bored me from beginning to end. Another thing is that this film hates to leave anything to imagination. Thus, little Georgie not only gets his arm bit off, but we have to see it in detail, then watch the kid crawl around, without his arm. Again: the film fails to generate sympathy and meaning, and treats us to nothing but gore. Why? Why would anyone make such a nasty film about kids, and even make it a remake of a wonderful film? This is bad film making, the kind that makes you want to throw up. The people who made this have no artistic ambition, and they are utterly cynical.

Ironically, they do reflect the soulless, nihilist age we live in, in which there is no truth or beauty, and nothing to fight and die for. The courage the kids muster at the end of the film won't do them any good in this world, because they will have nothing of any value to fight and sacrifice for. Value no longer exists. Only search for pleasure. And that kills the soul. Just as this film killed everything good about the original.

title: A great movie that lives up to the hype.
review: IT is one of the best horrors of the last 10 years in my opinion. Using many different camera angles to draw fright Andrés Muschietti really tries to make IT a visual feast. At times the CGI is a letdown, with many of the monsters (especially a flute painting) looking unrealistic, however this is made up for with the amazing looking Pennywise, who does not fail to live up to Tim Curry's well regarded performance. When the movie focuses on the story of the losers club and their personal bullies, IT shines, the characters have great chemistry that really forwards the story, and each character has their own distinct personality's. All in all, IT was a great movie that lived up to the hype.

title: Good special effects, decent acting, TERRIBLE writing and directing.
review:
A few weeks before this film was released, I started reading Stephen King's original novel for "IT". After dedicating several weeks to reading "IT", I was honestly blown away by how wonderfully detailed and immersive the setting, the plot, and the overarching journey was. But above all else, what I loved MOST about the novel, were the characters. I just want to say that the 2017 adaptation was not technically "Bad" objectively speaking, but it failed to capture that which was most precious in its source material; its CHARACTERS.

I have a lot of love for each of these adorable little 11 year olds, so let me just say that I am incredibly biased toward the original novel. I recognize that. But I feel like I would being doing a great disservice to myself and the book if I didn't explain WHAT this film did wrong.

One of the things the book did so well is to draw you into this homely setting of Derry by carefully introducing you to these misfit preteens who were still figuring out their place in the universe. It gives great care in introducing their personality, their quirks, their family life, and their interaction with other characters. However, now they all seem to be just randomly thrown together for no other reason than plot convenience.

Bill Denbrough: His character is one shrouded in guilt over his baby brother's death. He believes that he unwittingly sent his brother toward his his own demise, that he should have gone with him, and that somehow he could have saved him. This frequently haunts him throughout the course of the story, but in the film, we see NONE of the hatred and shame he forces upon himself. Why? Because the film washes away any sort of finality to Georgie's death by making him go "Missing" instead of making him bleed out from having his arm ripped off like the wing off a fly. This leads bill down a path of hope and optimism that he may still be alive down in the sewers. Bill's hatred for the thing that killed him brother and divided his family is not portrayed at all.

Ben Hanscom: Something the movie somewhat got right was Ben's introverted and bookish nature. Something I was hopeful to see more of. Unfortunately, his character is skimped over like most of the other characters in this movie. He only serves the purpose of being the "Smart one" and being the puppet of an unnecessary love triangle between Beverly and Bill.

Beverly Marsh: There were many things the film did wrong to Bev's character. From the first moment we see her, she's being harassed by over the top "Mean Girl" stereotypes, calling her a "Slut" for no adequately explored reason. After she inexplicably makes friends with a total stranger (Ben Hanscom) she is personified by being the victim of sexual abuse by her father. What the film fails to recognize, is the reality that victims of domestic abuse, still tend to love their abuser. But instead of taking the realistic approach, the film turns her into this closeted bad ass who strips half naked in front of 6 boys, sunbathes in front of them, then cracks her father's skull open like a pinata. She overcame her struggles and is now a stronger person because of it, right? Then she's randomly abducted by Pennywise and turned into the stereotypical damsel in distress in need of saving.

Richie Tozier: Not really much to say about him. The actor who played him was decent and recognizable, but all he seemed to do was shout out vulgarities and abandon his friends when they needed him most. Also he's scared of clowns for a reason the writers forgot to mention.

Stanley Uris: He served no purpose in the film at all. In the book, he was the cold realist of the group who enjoyed bird watching and had a sound logical mind. In the film his only distinguishing characteristic is that he's a flat footed coward, and that he's Jewish. Something of which the film seems to bring a lot of attention to considering it has no significance to the plot. He now has unexplained daddy issues and is afraid of a weird painting.

Eddie Kaspbrak: Probably the ONLY character in the movie that was fully developed by the end of the film. He is seen being coddled by his mother, forced to take heaps of medication, and is paranoid about practically everything that might make him sick. At the end, after discovering his medication wasn't real, and his mother absurdly sends his friends away, Eddie gets MAD. He tells her what he truly thinks, and throws away his "Medicine". The only thing that his development ignores is the fact that Eddie's brain physically believes that the "Medicine" works. That his body will literally go into withdraws and make him believe he's having an asthma attack. Something that stays with him for 27 years.

Mike Hanlon: Mike was another missed opportunity. Mike was taught by his father that he would always face strife because of who he was, and that one day he would know the time to fight back. Mike fought back plenty in the film, but the original topics of racism were greatly watered down and were only subtly hinted at instead of being an integral part of his original character.

All in all, the characters in this film did not meet my expectation and overall felt like they were cut and paste renditions of already established tropes. The bond that these seven children held in the original source material was non-existent in my eyes. From forced love triangles to uncharacteristic squabbling, I feel that IT (2017) did an extremely poor job of portraying Stephen King's beloved characters.

title: Exceeded Even My High Expectations
review:
Stephen King's book "It" is my single favorite fiction novel of all-time. I have read it a number of times and am completely and utterly absorbed by its atmosphere and characters. As such, despite the big buildup, promising trailers, and positive reviews, I wasn't sure that this new film adaptation could ever quite live up to my extremely heightened expectations. Fifteen minutes into my trip to the cinema, I knew I was wrong. This one was going to be great.

For a basic plot summary, "It" tells the story of the little Maine town of Derry, which seems to have a problem with children disappearing. During the time period this film focuses on, little Georgie Denbrough (Jackson Robert Scott) is attacked and killed by a maniacal clown named Pennywise (Bill Skarsgard) in a sewer grate. That starts a pattern of child abductions (the cycle beginning again in Derry), which is seemingly only realized by the "Losers Club", a group of friends who come together because they really don't fit in anywhere else:

-Bill (Jaeden Lieberher), Georgie's older brother, is struggling to come to terms with the family tragedy, an event that afflicted him with a pronounced stutter. -Ben (Jeremy Ray Taylor), the "fat kid" (pardon the judgment...this would have been me) of the group. -Richie (Finn Wolfhard), the loudmouth prankster. -Eddie (Jack Dylan Grazer), the sickly drink of water with the overbearing mother. -Mike (Chosen Jacobs), the black kid in a community not always accepting of minorities. -Stanley (Wyatt Oleff), the Jewish kid who struggles to even fit in with this gang. -Bev (Sophia Lillis), the girl that of course all the others have a huge crush on.

Over the course of that summer, the Losers Club is tormented by neighborhood bully Henry Bowers (Nicholas Hamilton), while at the same time all seeing manifestations of "It", a seemingly non-corporeal being who can transform into their greatest fears (e.g. Pennywise the maniacal clown).

Director Andy Muschietti's "It" is by no means a direct adaptation of the book. The best ones aren't, as they are two completely different mediums. Some of the characters go in different directions, some events are slightly altered, and even the time frame (1950s in the book) is moved up to the 1980s here.

What doesn't change, however, is the spirit of the source material. King's novel is all about coming of age, facing fears, and having courage when no one else will. All of those things are perfectly present here. A lot of that has to do with the acting performances, starting with the camaraderie between the young child actors. This may be the best child-led ensemble cast I've ever seen on the big screen, as their antics provide some much-needed levity for material that can be very dark. Then, of course, there is Skarsgard's Pennywise, which is just as iconic as Tim Curry's earlier take on the role (this one being much more dark and violent).

A final interesting observation is how "It" so seamlessly melded together the horror, adventure, and thriller genres. If you are a fan of either, you'll find something to enjoy. The scary scenes are something straight out of, say, "The Conjuring", while the buddy adventure is so much like "Stranger Things" (Wolfhard double dipping even!) that one could almost call "copycat" (but it's so fun who cares?!). Backing everything up is a very solid story.

Of course, this is only the first chapter in the "It" story, as King's book also goes into great detail about these characters as adults. That material is saved for a later-date sequel, and this one sets it up perfectly. This original can be viewed as a stand-alone experience, yet leaves just enough unanswered questions to make a compelling "part two".

Overall, "It" was one of my favorite film-going experiences in quite some time. It did justice to a great story, even introduced some new aspects into the mix, and whetted appetites for more to come. I can't wait to return to Derry for Round Two in the future!

title: It really is that bad
review:
The kids were all extrodinary in their roles.

And that is the only redeeming factor of this terrible adaptation of Stephen King's classic novel.

Every other aspect from this movie, from the writing, editing, directing, you name it, is unforgivably flawed. I wish I could say I was simply "let down", but this is seriously one of the worst films I have ever seen.

Without the aid of the original miniseries, and/or the novel, there is no reason to care about any of these characters, and no way to even understand what the film is even about. There's virtually no story to any part of this move.

And the CGI, seriously!!!! Wow. I can generally look past obvious CGI effects in other films. But this isn't your normal "obvious CGI" this is really really really BAD "obvious CGI".

Aside from the parts in the preview, there is not one scene of pennywise that isn't laughably executed. From the first encounter with Georgie, to the ridiculous dances, to the awful ending. This film has ruined an iconic horror movie antagonist, and the worst part about it, is that they're going to make another one.

I'm not sure exactly what went wrong, or where they went wrong, because every single aspect (aside from the acting of the main 7) is just wrong.

To say I'm disappointed would be a vast understatement. The PR team however, deserves commending for keeping the rating well above what it deserves. Forget horror movie, this is just a bad bad bad bad bad movie.

Save your money, safe your time, save yourself from enduring this forgettable train wreck of a film.

title: Even with some flaws, this horror movie still had the IT-Factor. It was very entertaining.
review: Once upon a time, clowns used to bring out, joy out of children. Then, author, Stephen King's 1986's horror novel, 'It' came out of nowhere and nearly destroy that industry; by causing 'coulrophobia' AKA 'the fear of clowns' to become more common. While, it's true, that a few scary tricksters in novels, had existed for a very long time; such as author, Edgar Allen Poe's 1849's short story 'HopFrog', 1892 Italian opera, 'Pagliacci', and most recently, the Joker from Detective Comic's 'Batman' fame from the 1940s. Stephen King's novel takes the carnivalesque performance into a bizarre, but interesting direction by having a mysterious out of this world being, exploited the fears and phobias of its childhood victims by disguising itself with the form of a clown, in order to devour them. If you think, this plot already sounds crazy. I haven't gotten to, the outrageous meat of this novel; which includes under-aged gang-bang, statues of Paul Bunyan coming to live, cosmic turtles, and odd rituals against Universal Movie Monsters. Not only that, but the book was divide, by two major story arches: one focusing on the kids, trying to survive, and the other chapter, the kids reunited as adults to finally attempt to kill the beast. All of this, is way too much for a story! It's come across, as muddled, excessive, and highly gimmicky. That's why, this novel is highly regarded, as one of Stephen King's weakest books & often view as not filmable. Nevertheless, it didn't stop, movie studios from trying; as in 1990, the novel was adapted into a television miniseries starring Tim Curry as the demonic clown. For the most part, the miniseries was a lot better than the book as it omitted a lot of the craziest, and stupider stuff, however, it was still total crap for its bad acting, awful cheesy effects, and pacing issues. Although, the miniseries has many flaws, it has gather, a cult following over the years to the point, that a remake was welcome. In 2017, we got that reboot, and it was surprising, pretty damn good. Not perfect, but entertaining enough, to overlook, its flaws. Directed by Andy Muschietti, with a screenplay by Chase Palmer, Cary Fukunaga and Gary Dauberman. The film really does a good job, cutting the fat. Instead of a dual anachronic order narrative, the film purely focuses on the development of the characters as children; meaning no awkward repetitive flashbacks; making more of a tighter film. However, there was still a structure for this coming to age horror movie, I didn't like. The way, the film intermixed the lighthearted comedy like boy bands with the disturbing imagery aspect of dead people was a bit jarring. It was kinda weird to see characters, in a state of unpleasant anxiety, one second, due to an attempt attack by Pennywise (Bill Skarsgård) or sadistic bullies like Henry Bowers (Nicholas Hamilton), only for a few minutes, be alright to go outside to hang out with friends at the lake. Also the idea, that these children would be alright, in staying in a town, where a mysterious creatures kills people, the whole summer, was also a bit unrealistic. In truth, these children should be, more scar for life & living in paranoia, than they were. They should be locked up in their house, ready for anything, since the movie never explain, how Pennywise can get you, or not. The idea that they can coexisted with this creature, around, is, insane. Also, the span of the tragic events, should only, take, place, during a couple of days, not weeks. Furthermore, the third act of one of them, getting caught, a month after the last attack, seems a bit force, rush, and highly clichés. The whole damsel in distress, love triangle third act was not great. Despite that, the CGI visual effects and practical makeup effects were great, during the action moments. Lots of really frightening moments like that projector scene; throughout the movie; only a few of them, were duds, like the leper. I just wish, the movie could be, a little more subtle with some of the jump scares like they did with the creepy librarian and the television show playing in the background. Way too many loud noises, kinda ruins the suspense. Nevertheless, Bill Skarsgård does a great job as Pennywise, even if the film doesn't attempt to make his character seem, that deceiving as a villain. I love how one of Pennywise's eyes is always fixed on the camera, giving the impression that he can see the audience watching the movie. So creepy. As for the children, the acting from them, is also great. Mad props goes to Jaeden Lieberher, Sophia Lillis & Finn Wolfhard as Bill Denbrough, Beverly Marsh, and Richie Tozier. They did a hell of a job, making these characters, seem real. I really got the loss of innocence story, even if the update piece remind me of a gorier version of Netflix's TV Series, 'Stranger Things', with its homage to 1980s nostalgia. Overall: It's a must watch from me. Highly recommended. Even, Stephen King himself was very happy with the movie after seeing it early. 'It' was a fun enough thrill ride. This movie truly does float.

title: As good as any circus sideshow: a few surprises with a dancing clown and then you leave and forget about it.
review:
"It" is not a scary movie. It's a special effects show with an 80's vibe brought about via the popularity of "Stranger Things," an overrated Goonies-inspired TV drama. ("The Goonies" sucks, by the way.) Still here? Cool.

Now all you thick-skinned folks and I can sit down and talk. We knew going in that "It" is not scary: the woman who brought her wailing infant into the cinema this evening (seriously) illustrates this: but is "It" a decent show? Sure. As good as any circus sideshow. A few surprises with a dancing clown and then you leave, instantly forgetting about it.

"It's" (It, with an apostrophe? Wow, confusing) problem is that most of its scares are jump-shocks (cheap!), and, get ready for the obvious: its dated setting. NOBODY goes to the circus anymore (did they even have the circus in the 1980s?) and evil clowns are old, old hat. Ever since Batman arrested the Joker for public nudity in the 1960s has the idea of clowns being evil been super-ultra-cliché. (Did you know that a "Joker" origin movie is in the works? Lame! Doesn't that just make your eyes roll?) However, props to Bill Skarsgård's acting, and his conveniently wall-eyed appearance: with those eyes, you never know if he's looking at you or for you (teehee). Kudos also for that kid with the glasses who never stops swearing: he's the fun one of the group, when all the others won't shut up about their problems.
